[@zach](@ZqH7Mctu/7DNInxuwl12ECjfrAKUX2tBLq1rOldNhg0=.ed25519)

I'm not sure which sort of interface would be best, I'm thinking that I could do something standalone, within Patchbay, or both (like ssb-chess). One of my thoughts was showing gossip activity since it's [hard to debug](%M0Cveu/Kbl3yLG3gonrY2r1YCRCXvekMKRRXKbmxKek=.sha256), but it looks like [@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) may have [read my mind](%+U0LnC6hc8S607e7vgS2+6Icso7zlpgI27zBWM/Yii0=.sha256)!

> what would prompt someone to want to look under the hood

I think there are all sorts of low-level bugs that people experience (endless "scuttling", forked feeds, gossip failure) and maintenance tasks that people may want to do (e.g. delete a feed) that would be nice to handle in one application.

> what sort of answer or insight (in the form of code or otherwise) would they expect to find

I'm thinking something like:

- list of all of the feeds in your database
  - add raw data to your feed
  - delete other feeds from your database
  - follow, unfollow, or block feeds
- list all of the blobs in your filesystem
  - add blobs to the filesystem
  - delete blobs from the filesystem
  - get messages that reference blobs
- list of all the peers in your `gossip.json`
  - add peer to the gossip file
  - delete peer from gossip file
  - get real-time network activity, including errors and statistics
  - get network history, including errors and statistics
- make backups
  - all of the above should be able to be backed up or restored from a backup
  - possible #dark-crystal integration to shard password for backup (or just keypair)
- list all flumedb views
  - get indexing progress on each view
  - get ETA until indexing is complete (and maybe statistics on progress)
- create [benchmarks](%kuxL79vQ1f+ZqaIFu3srHRTov2xA0nX7MRC5cUCSwY8=.sha256) to see how the software performance changes over time

I think a lot of the lower-level bits of Scuttlebutt can actually be pretty intuitive if people feel empowered to tinker and/or troubleshoot by themselves, and I don't think we have very much infrastructure for that right now.
